Dear Sir:

I have the honor to inform you that you have been elected a member of
THE SOCIETY FOR THE EXTENSION OF UNIVERSITY TEACHING,

George Henderson

UNIVERSITY EXTENSION.
I. THE AIM AND SCOPE OF THE MOVEMENT.

The purpose of the University Extension movement is to
provide the means of higher education for persons of all classes
and of both sexes engaged in the regular occupations of life. It
is, in fact, an attempt to solve the problem of how much of
what the Universities do for their own students can be done for
persons unable to go to a University.

The movement was started in 1872 by the University of
Cambridge, and the work has been carried on in England with
increasing success. Last year nearly forty thousand students
attended courses of lectures at about three hundred centres in
England and Wales.

The fundamental idea throughout has been education for
busy people. The majority of the courses have been given in
the evening, and the audiences have included persons drawn
from all ranks of society and of the widest diversity of previous
education and training. Ladies, business and professional men,
clerks, tradespeople, and teachers in schools have all been rep-
resented in the lecture-audiences; while the courses in East
London and Northern part of England have been largely
attended by working-people.
METHOD OF WORK.

The work in Philadelphia is under the management and
supervision of the Philadelphia Society for the Extension of
University Teaching, which will act in close connection with the
University of Pennsylvania, Jefferson Medical College, Lehigh
University, Bryn Mawr, Swarthmore, Haverford, Lafayette and
Franklin and Marshall Colleges, Academy of Natural Sciences,
the Young Men's Christian Association, the Pennsylvania Mu-
seum and School of Industrial Art, and other teaching bodies.

In order to make the teaching at the same time attractive
to those who merely desire to attend the lectures, and thor-
oughly educational for students who wish to make a more sys-
tematic study of the subject, a special method is followed.

(1) LECTURES.--The Courses consist of from six to twelve weekly or fort-
nightly lectures, given during the three months before Christmas, called the
First Term, or the three months after Christmas, called the Second Term,
each lecture occupying an hour.

(2) CLASS.--For about three-quarters of an hour preceding or following each
lecture, a class is held for those students who wish to study the subject more
thoroughly. The object of the class is to give the students an opportunity of
coming into personal contact with the Lecturer, in order that they may, by
conversation and discussion with him, the better familiarize their minds with
the principles of the subject, and get their special difficulties explained. The
teaching in the class is conversational.

(3) SYLLABUS.--In order to enable students to follow the lecture readily, and
carry away the substance of it, a printed syllabus, usually in pamphlet form,
is prepared beforehand by the Lecturer for the use of the students, and sold at
a low price.

(4) WEEKLY PAPERS.--Questions are set on each lecture, which may be an-
swered by the students, in writing at home, and submitted to the Lecturer for
correction and comment.

(5) EXAMINATION.--At the end of the Course an Examination is held by the
Lecturer, and only thoses students are admitted to the Examinations who have
attended the lectures and classes to the satisfaction of the Lecturer, and have
done such an amount of weekly paper work as the Lecturer may have required.

(6) CERTIFICATES.--Certificates are awarded in connection with these
Courses to those who satisfy the Lecturer in the weekly work and pass the
Examination.
THE SUCCESS OF THE METHOD.

The success which has attended the working of this method
in England, has proved that the attainment of a very high stand-
ard of training and knowledge is possible by attendance at Uni-
versity Extension Courses, provided the student carries out the
system in its entirety.

It will be seen, therefore, that this system is adapted at the
same time to persons who desire merely a general acquaintance-
ship with the subjects taught, as well as to students who are
anxious to make a more thorough study. The courses have
covered various departments in Science, Literature, History,
Economics and Art, and have been fully illustrated, where nec-
essary, with experiments and diagrams or the lantern.

THE PHILADELPHIA SOCIETY
FOR THE
EXTENSION OF UNIVERSITY TEACHING

has been organized to promote the effort in an educational field
which has been hitherto almost entirely neglected. The univer-
sal establishment of public free schools, and their results in
removing illiteracy, are matters of such recent date that we are
just beginning to realize what excellent foundations they furnish
upon which to build higher and higher the educational structures

of general society. At present vast numbers are compelled by
the needs of livelihood to leave school at an early age, and very
many more who can continue long enough to secure a good
common school education are still unable to share in the privi-
leges of higher education, which at present requires prolonged
attendance upon College or University courses. This is a pri-
vate misfortune to the many, as well as a great public weakness
in the State, and the best energies of all who are interested
in the public welfare should be earnestly exerted to seek out
and apply a remedy. In England the great Universities have
established courses of University teaching in cities, towns and
villages throughout the kingdom wherever an opportunity can
be found or created, and the success of their efforts is shown
by the fact that during the past year more than 40,000 students
enjoyed the advantages of such instruction. Here, where the
conditions are different, though the need is as great, this work
must be done by a strong and intelligent organization of citi-
zens, working in close connection with the existing teaching
bodies which afford facilities for higher education. Our Society
has been organized in the belief that the task which it attempts
will invite general co-operation. It seems clear that the scheme
will invite general co-operation. It seems clear that the scheme
to open out University courses of standard value and character
in Science, Art, Literature and History to thousands and tens
of thousands of intelligent workers, and to do it in such a way
that the studies can be pursued leisurely and without drawing
the students from the work by which they earn their living,
must command a cordial support. Courses of lectures and
classes have been, or soon will be, established in at least six
suitable locations within the city, as also at Roxborough, Frank-
ford and other outlying points, and the efficiency of the work
done at these local centres, or at others still to be selected, will
largely depend on the strength and enthusiasm of the Society's
membership. The annual fee has been fixed at $5.00 in the
hope that all interested in the work will lend their aid. Mem-
bers of the Society are privileged to attend any of its courses
free of charge.

The report of the Secretary, who has been abroad all Sum-
mer, studying the movement in England, which contains a
detailed account of the University Extension work in that
country, is ready for distribution and will be sent post free upon
application.

Prof. Skidmore's article from the August number of
Lippincott's Magazine, upon University Extension, has been
reprinted and will also be sent. For further information address
the Secretary.

UNIVERSITY EXTENSION ASSOCIATION
